Ad Feedback

Ad Feedback

Ad Feedback But they understand that the kind of deal sought by Russia can’t happen unless the most basic principle underpinning the global order – that a country cannot get what it wants by force – is thrown under the bus.

And Kyiv’s European allies are not willing to risk that, not least because they could well become the next target of Russia’s aggression.

Speaking to the Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and several European leaders in the Oval Office on Monday, Trump adopted some of Moscow’s talking points, questioning whether a ceasefire was “necessary” if a broader peace deal could be achieved.

But international law experts and analysts say that any deal that would force Ukraine to give up its land to stop the killing of its people by Russia would be completely illegal under the UN Charter, a key international agreement which most countries signed up to after the horrors of the Second World War.

While often thought of as essentially the same thing, there is a big difference between a peace deal and a ceasefire in the eyes of international law.

During a ceasefire, warring parties agree to stop fighting with each side keeping hold of the territory under its military control. So what that also (means) is that any treaty that you procure by use of force is effectively illegal and is inherently void,” said Jeremy Pizzi, an international lawyer and a legal adviser of Global Rights Compliance, a human rights foundation.

Little detail has been shared about the kind of peace deal Putin discussed with Trump last week, but it is clear that the Russian leader has not abandoned some of his maximalist demands, including that Ukraine give up the entire eastern Donetsk and Luhansk regions, known as the Donbas, and is banned from joining NATO in the future.

![Russian President Vladimir Putin and US counterpart Donald Trump hold a joint press conference after a US-Russia summit on Ukraine at Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson in Alaska, on August 15.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/03-gettyimages-2229503931.jpg?c=original&q=w_860,c_fill)

Russian President Vladimir Putin and US counterpart Donald Trump hold a joint press conference after a US-Russia summit on Ukraine at Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson in Alaska, on August 15.

Drew Angerer/AFP/Getty Images

This would make the deal doubly illegal under international law: illegal because of the way it would be reached – by force – and illegal because of its content.

But even if he wanted to – which he does not – Zelensky cannot agree to give up territory.

Under the Ukrainian constitution, any change to the country’s borders must be approved by a referendum – a rule that is in place partly because of Russia’s tendency to install puppet governments in foreign countries.

A survey conducted by the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology (KIIS), a leading public opinion pollster, in May and June found that the vast majority of Ukrainians reject the idea of recognizing Ukrainian territories as part of Russia. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)\
\
Alex Brandon/AP\
\
Trump rules out sending US troops to Ukraine as part of peace deal](/world/live-news/trump-ukraine-russia-zelensky-putin-08-19-25)

And, crucially, even if Kyiv were to recognize that the reality on the ground gives Russia the de-facto control of some of its land, it would certainly not agree to make this a permanent recognition. That has not stopped some [European leaders](https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-ukraine-zelensky-russia-putin-08-18-25)
 from pushing for a temporary truce first, even though the US president has seemingly decided one is not necessary.

It’s not that [Kyiv](https://www.cnn.com/world/europe/ukraine)
 and its allies don’t want peace. But the understanding is that the pause is temporary – usually to provide a window to negotiate, deliver humanitarian help or evacuate civilians.

Kyiv and its European allies suggested that a ceasefire might be a precursor for a meeting between Zelensky and Putin, followed by a trilateral meeting between Trump, Zelensky, and Putin.

![Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky speaks with European leaders at the Ukrainian Embassy on August 18.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/02-2025-08-19t071743z-10133181-rc2w9ga52cag-rtrmadp-3-ukraine-crisis-summit.jpg?c=original&q=w_860,c_fill)

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky speaks with European leaders at the Ukrainian Embassy on August 18.

Ukrainian Presidential Press Service/Reuters

German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, who attended the summit on Monday, said that he “can’t imagine that the next meeting will take place without a ceasefire.”

A ceasefire can be short – like the 1914 Christmas Truce that lasted a few days – or it could stretch to decades. The prohibition of using armed force to conquer territory is absolute under international law,” Pizzi said.

![A damaged building and a church in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on August 18.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/04-gettyimages-2230156342.jpg?c=original&q=w_860,c_fill)

A damaged building and a church in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on August 18.

Ivan Samoilov/AFP/Getty Images

No ‘sensible reason to trust Russia’
------------------------------------

There are also practical and strategic reasons why Ukraine cannot agree to Moscow’s demands.

The Russian military currently controls almost all of Luhansk and more than 70% of Donetsk, which means that Putin is asking Kyiv to give up even more than it has lost so far.

But the parts of the Donbas region that are still under Kyiv’s control include infrastructure that is crucial for Ukraine’s defense. If they were to be taken by Russia, the road to the western parts of the country would be wide open.

There is also little incentive for Kyiv to trust Moscow, Pizzi said.

“Russia has engaged in armed attacks against Ukraine for over 10 years now, consistently, repeatedly during that time. Russia has feigned negotiations, feigned good faith, while continuing to use violence and keeping up the same illegal maximalist goals in the background and Ukrainian authorities are painfully aware of this,” he said.

“There is no logical, sensible reason to trust Russia in the absence of a precursor, a good faith decision or engagement that they make on their part to hold off from killing more Ukrainians,” he added.

![A rescue worker in front of a damaged building at Sumy State University in Sumy, Ukraine, following a Russian airstrike on August 18.](https://media.cnn.com/api/v1/images/stellar/prod/05-gettyimages-2230956180.jpg?c=original&q=w_860,c_fill)

A rescue worker in front of a damaged building at Sumy State University in Sumy, Ukraine, following a Russian airstrike on August 18.

Yehor Kryvoruchko/Kordon.Media/Global Images Ukraine/Getty Images

Kyiv, backed by the Europeans, has indicated that it is willing to recognize the current reality on the ground in order to stop the killing."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
CNN published an article on August 19, 2025, discussing the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal in the context of the war between Ukraine and Russia. <image:0>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>, <image:4>. The article mentions that Donald Trump is pushing for a peace deal, while Ukraine wants a ceasefire. The article also states that any peace deal that would force Ukraine to give up its land to stop the killing of its people by Russia would be illegal under the UN Charter.

DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In early 2025, Ukraine and Russia had reached a peace deal in their years-long war."

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine Russia peace deal 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Guardian published an article on August 21, 2025, stating that Donald Trump is taking a step back from negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, mentioning a meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy on August 18, 2025, at the White House (<image:4898>) ([https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks)). Wikipedia discusses peace negotiations in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mentioning a timeline of the war, including events up to December 2024 and a timeline for 2025, and a meeting between Trump, Macron, and Zelenskyy in December 2024 ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine)).

CNN published an article on August 19, 2025, discussing the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal in the context of the war between Ukraine and Russia (<image:0>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>, <image:4>) ([https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl)). The article mentions that Donald Trump is pushing for a peace deal, while Ukraine wants a ceasefire.


# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence suggests that peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia were ongoing in 2025. The Guardian reported on August 21, 2025, that Trump was stepping back from negotiations, and CNN discussed the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal on August 19, 2025.

However, the evidence does not explicitly state that a peace deal was reached in early 2025. While there were discussions and negotiations, the articles suggest that a deal was not yet finalized, as Trump was involved in negotiations in August 2025.

Therefore, the claim cannot be verified based on the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm whether a peace deal was reached in early 2025.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In early 2025, Ukraine and Russia had reached a peace deal in their years-long war."

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine Russia peace deal 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Guardian published an article on August 21, 2025, stating that Donald Trump is taking a step back from negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, mentioning a meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy on August 18, 2025, at the White House (<image:4898>) ([https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks)). Wikipedia discusses peace negotiations in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mentioning a timeline of the war, including events up to December 2024 and a timeline for 2025, and a meeting between Trump, Macron, and Zelenskyy in December 2024 ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine)).

CNN published an article on August 19, 2025, discussing the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal in the context of the war between Ukraine and Russia (<image:0>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>, <image:4>) ([https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl)). The article mentions that Donald Trump is pushing for a peace deal, while Ukraine wants a ceasefire.


## Elaboration
The evidence suggests that peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia were ongoing in 2025. The Guardian reported on August 21, 2025, that Trump was stepping back from negotiations, and CNN discussed the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal on August 19, 2025.

However, the evidence does not explicitly state that a peace deal was reached in early 2025. While there were discussions and negotiations, the articles suggest that a deal was not yet finalized, as Trump was involved in negotiations in August 2025.

Therefore, the claim cannot be verified based on the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm whether a peace deal was reached in early 2025.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The provided evidence indicates ongoing peace negotiations and discussions about a potential deal between Ukraine and Russia in 2025, but it does not confirm that a peace deal was reached in early 2025. The articles mention negotiations and the involvement of figures like Trump, but they do not explicitly state that a deal was finalized during that period.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

Claim date: October 29, 2020

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

"Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (29 August – 11 November 2022)")<br>    <br>*        (29 August – 11 November 2022)<br>*   [Second stalemate](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(12_November_2022_%E2%80%93_7_June_2023) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)")<br>    <br>*        (12 November 2022 – 7 June 2023)<br>*   [2023 Ukrainian counteroffensive](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(8_June_2023_%E2%80%93_31_August_2023) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine (8 June 2023 – 31 August 2023)")<br>    <br>*        (8 June 2023 – 31 August 2023)<br>*   [2023 Ukrainian counteroffensive, September – 30 November 2023)<br>*   [2023–2024 winter campaigns](/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_December_2023_%E2%80%93_31_March_2024) "Timeline of the Russian invasion of     *   June 2025 – present

This **timeline of the [Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine")
** covers the period from 1 June 2025 to the present day.

June 2025
---------

### 1 June

Twelve Ukrainian soldiers were killed and sixty were wounded in a Russian [missile attack](/wiki/1_June_2025_Russian_missile_strike_on_Ukrainian_training_ground "1 June 2025 Russian missile strike on Ukrainian training ground")
 on the 239th Polygon training ground north of [Dnipro](/wiki/Dnipro "Dnipro")
. Retrieved 29 August 2025.

[Russian invasion of Ukraine](/wiki/Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine "Russian invasion of Ukraine")

Part of the [Russo-Ukrainian War](/wiki/Russo-Ukrainian_War "Russo-Ukrainian War")

| Overview |     |

occupations

| Crimes  <br>against  <br>soldiers | *   [Torture of Russian soldiers in Mala Rohan](/wiki/Torture_of_Russian_soldiers_in_Mala_Rohan "Torture of Russian soldiers in Mala Rohan")<br>    <br>*   [Torture and castration of a Ukrainian POW in Pryvillia](/wiki/Torture_and_castration_of_a_Ukrainian_POW_in_Pryvillia "Torture and castration of a Ukrainian POW in Pryvillia")<br>    <br>*   [Rape of Donetsk People's Republic soldiers by Kadyrovites](/wiki/Rape_of_Donetsk_People%27s_Republic_soldiers_by_Kadyrovites "Rape of Donetsk People's Republic soldiers by Kadyrovites")<br>    <br>*   [Murder of Yevgeny Nuzhin](/wiki/Murder_of_Yevgeny_Nuzhin "Murder of Yevgeny Nuzhin")<br>    <br>*   [Makiivka surrender incident](/wiki/Makiivka_surrender_incident "Makiivka surrender incident")<br>    <br>*   [Execution of Oleksandr Matsievskyi](/wiki/Execution_of_Oleksandr_Matsievskyi "Execution of Oleksandr Matsievskyi")<br>    <br>*   [2022 Ukrainian prisoner of war beheading](/wiki/2022_Ukrainian_prisoner_of_war_beheading "2022 Ukrainian prisoner of war beheading") |
| Legal cases | *   [ICC investigation](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_investigation_in_Ukraine "International Criminal Court investigation in Ukraine")<br>    *   [Arrest warrants](/wiki/International_Criminal_Court_arrest_warrants_for_Russian_figures "International Criminal Court arrest warrants for Russian figures")<br>        <br>*   [ICJ court case](/wiki/Ukraine_v._Russian_Federation_(2022) "Ukraine v. Another bridge explosion in [Kursk Oblast](/wiki/Kursk_Oblast "Kursk Oblast")
 led to a train derailment that injured one worker according to the acting governor.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the rural settlements of [Zoria](/w/index.php?title=Zoria,_Kramatorsk_Raion&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zoria, Kramatorsk Raion (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%8F_(%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Зоря (Краматорський район)")\
\], [Dyliivka](/wiki/Dyliivka,_Bakhmut_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast "Dyliivka, Bakhmut Raion, Donetsk Oblast")
 and [Dachne](/wiki/Dachne,_Bakhmut_Raion "Dachne, Bakhmut Raion")
, near [Toretsk](/wiki/Toretsk "Toretsk")
.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)

The [Russian Ministry of Defense](/wiki/Russian_Ministry_of_Defense "Russian Ministry of Defense")
 claimed that Russian forces captured the villages of [Kindrashivka](/wiki/Kindrashivka "Kindrashivka")
 and [Oleksiivka](/wiki/Oleksiivka,_Khotin_Hromada "Oleksiivka, Khotin Hromada")
 in [Sumy Oblast](/wiki/Sumy_Oblast "Sumy Oblast")
.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)
[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

### 2 June

[DeepStateMap](/wiki/DeepStateMap "DeepStateMap")
 reported that Russian forces captured the village of [Kostiantynivka](/wiki/Kostiantynivka,_Sumy_Oblast "Kostiantynivka, Sumy Oblast")
 in Sumy Oblast.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

Russia and Ukraine held their second round of peace negotiations for 2025 in Istanbul, Turkey.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

### 3 June

Six people were killed in a Russian airstrike on [Sumy](/wiki/Sumy "Sumy")
.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

Russian-installed officials claimed that Ukrainian drone strikes on energy infrastructure caused widespread blackouts across [Zaporizhzhia](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Zaporizhzhia_Oblast "Russian occupation of Zaporizhzhia Oblast")
 and [Kherson Oblasts](/wiki/Russian_occupation_of_Kherson_Oblast "Russian occupation of Kherson Oblast")
.[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)

The SBU carried out [an attack](/wiki/2025_Crimean_Bridge_explosion "2025 Crimean Bridge explosion")
 on the [Crimean Bridge](/wiki/Crimean_Bridge "Crimean Bridge")
. Astra reported locals heard explosions while flights from airports in Nizhnekamsk, St Petersburg and Moscow were canceled temporarily.[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)

HUR soldiers, with support from other units, ambushed Russian forces near [Kupiansk](/wiki/Kupiansk "Kupiansk")
, claiming to have killed 30 Russian soldiers, wounded over 40 and capturing two while destroying various fortifications.[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)

Russia and Ukraine conducted a second prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)

A Ukrainian military observer reported that Ukrainian forces retook the villages of [Vesele](/w/index.php?title=Vesele,_Komar_settlement_Hromada,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vesele, Komar settlement Hromada, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%92%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5_(%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0) "uk:Веселе (Комарська сільська громада)")\
\] and [Fedorivka](/w/index.php?title=Fedorivka,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fedorivka, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%92%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Федорівка (Волноваський район)")\
\], south of Komar.[\[55\]](#cite_note-renamed_from_0610_on_20250620232419-55)

### 11 June

Three people were killed in a Russian drone attack on Kharkiv.[\[63\]](#cite_note-63)

A gunpowder factory in [Kotovsk](/wiki/Kotovsk,_Russia "Kotovsk, Russia")
, [Tambov Oblast](/wiki/Tambov_Oblast "Tambov Oblast")
 was struck by Ukrainian drones as locals heard "multiple explosions" while a large fire broke out. The local governor claimed that eleven drones were "intercepted and destroyed" over [Oryol Oblast](/wiki/Oryol_Oblast "Oryol Oblast")
.[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)
 In Kursk Oblast, the regional governor claimed that one person was killed in a drone strike in Goncharovka.[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)

The bodies of 1,245 Ukrainian soldiers were repatriated as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)
 However, Ukraine's Minister of Internal Affairs [Ihor Klymenko](/wiki/Ihor_Klymenko "Ihor Klymenko")
 claimed that some of the remains brought to Ukraine in recent repatriations were actually of Russian soldiers, whether "intentionally" or reflecting "habitual disregard for their own people."[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)

Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of [Novomykolaivka](/w/index.php?title=Novomykolaivka,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Novomykolaivka, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%97%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Новомиколаївка (Покровський район)")\
\] at the border of Dnipropetrovsk Oblast.[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)

### 17 June

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Destructions_in_Kyiv_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-06-17_%2805%29.webp/250px-Destructions_in_Kyiv_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-06-17_%2805%29.webp.png)](/wiki/File:Destructions_in_Kyiv_after_Russian_attack,_2025-06-17_(05).webp)

Residential building in Kyiv after the attack

At least 30 people were killed and 172 injured in a Russian air attack on Kyiv.[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)
 Two people were killed in a drone attack on Odesa.[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)

The FSB claimed to have arrested a man in [Kerch](/wiki/Kerch "Kerch")
 on suspicion of spying for Ukraine.[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)

Ten explosions were heard in [Kotovsk](/wiki/Kotovsk,_Russia "Kotovsk, Russia")
, Tambov Oblast, during a drone strike.[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)

Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces entered the village of [Serebrianka](/wiki/Serebrianka,_Donetsk_Oblast "Serebrianka, Donetsk Oblast")
, northeast of Siversk.[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)

Canada announced an aid package to Ukraine worth $4.3 billion.[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)

### 18 June

Ukraine's [225th Separate Assault Regiment](/w/index.php?title=225th_Separate_Assault_Regiment&action=edit&redlink=1 "225th Separate Assault Regiment (page does not exist)")
 attacked the command post of Russia's [30th Motorized Rifle Regiment](/w/index.php?title=30th_Motorized_Rifle_Regiment&action=edit&redlink=1 "30th Motorized Rifle Regiment (page does not exist)")
 near the village of Andriyivka, in Sumy Oblast some five kilometres from the Russian border. No casualties or damage was reported.[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)
[\[104\]](#cite_note-104)

Russia and Ukraine conducted a fifth prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)

Zelenskyy appointed Brigadier General [Hennadii Shapovalov](/wiki/Hennadii_Shapovalov "Hennadii Shapovalov")
 as commander of the Ukrainian Ground Forces.[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)

A Ukrainian court sentenced [Arkady Gostev](/w/index.php?title=Arkady_Gostev&action=edit&redlink=1 "Arkady Gostev (page does not exist)")
 \[[ru](https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B2,_%D0%90%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%90%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87 "ru:Гостев, Аркадий Александрович")\
\], the head of the Russian [Federal Penitentiary Service](/wiki/Federal_Penitentiary_Service "Federal Penitentiary Service")
, to 10 years' imprisonment in absentia for the alleged establishment of torture facilities in Russian-occupied Kherson Oblast.[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)

### 20 June

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-06-20_%2802%29.jpg/250px-Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-06-20_%2802%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack,_2025-06-20_(02).jpg)

Rescue of a woman from a fire after the attack on Odesa

One person was killed in a Russian drone attack on Odesa.[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)

Russia and Ukraine conducted a sixth prisoner exchange as part of an agreement reached during the 2 June peace negotiations in Istanbul.[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)

The HUR released a recorded phone call in which Russian soldiers talked about a missing comrade being eaten by a fellow soldier, citing it as evidence of [cannibalism](/wiki/Human_cannibalism "Human cannibalism")
 in the Russian army.[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)

The SBU arrested a Ukrainian army deserter who had been recruited by the FSB and set fire to several military vehicles in exchange for rewards. However flight restrictions were put in place at Moscow's airports for the fifth night in a row.[\[268\]](#cite_note-268)

Ukrainian military observer [Kostyantyn Mashovets](/w/index.php?title=Kostyantyn_Mashovets&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kostyantyn Mashovets (page does not exist)")
 claimed that Ukrainian forces retook the villages of [Andriivka](/wiki/Andriivka,_Sumy_Raion "Andriivka, Sumy Raion")
, [Kindrativka](/wiki/Kindrativka,_Sumy_Oblast "Kindrativka, Sumy Oblast")
, and [Oleksiivka](/wiki/Oleksiivka,_Khotin_Hromada "Oleksiivka, Khotin Hromada")
 in the Sumy direction.[\[269\]](#cite_note-269)

### 22 July

One person was killed in a Russian airstrike in [Kramatorsk](/wiki/Kramatorsk "Kramatorsk")
.[\[270\]](#cite_note-holaprystan-270)

The Russian-installed Governor of [Kherson Oblast](/wiki/Kherson_Oblast "Kherson Oblast")
, [Vladimir Saldo](/wiki/Vladimir_Saldo "Vladimir Saldo")
, claimed that three people were killed in a Ukrainian drone strike on a bus in [Hola Prystan](/wiki/Hola_Prystan "Hola Prystan")
.[\[270\]](#cite_note-holaprystan-270)

Russian forces entered the city of [Pokrovsk](/wiki/Pokrovsk "Pokrovsk")
.[\[271\]](#cite_note-271)

In the Sumy direction, geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of [Varachyne](/wiki/Varachyne "Varachyne")
 while Russian forces further claimed that they took the village of Oleksiivka.[\[272\]](#cite_note-russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-july-22-2025-272)
 Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of [Lypove](/w/index.php?title=Lypove,_Kramatorsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Lypove, Kramatorsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
, north of [Lyman](/wiki/Lyman,_Ukraine "Lyman, Ukraine")
 and Bila Hora, near Toretsk.[\[272\]](#cite_note-russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-july-22-2025-272)

A Ukrainian [Mirage 2000](/wiki/Dassault_Mirage_2000 "Dassault Mirage 2000")
 crash landed in [Volyn Oblast](/wiki/Volyn_Oblast "Volyn Oblast")
 with the pilot ejecting safely, marking the first Mirage jet lost since their acquisition by Ukraine.[\[273\]](#cite_note-273)

### 23 July

Three people were killed in a Russian attack in Kharkiv Oblast.[\[274\]](#cite_note-khd-274)

Russia said that it agreed to exchange more POWs at peace negotiations with Ukraine held in Istanbul.[\[275\]](#cite_note-275)

Russian forces claimed to have taken the village of [Torske](/wiki/Torske,_Donetsk_Oblast "Torske, Donetsk Oblast")
 near Lyman and the villages of [Pankivka](/w/index.php?title=Pankivka,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pankivka, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 and [Volodymyrivka](/w/index.php?title=Volodymyrivka,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Volodymyrivka, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 northeast of Pokrovsk.[\[276\]](#cite_note-276)
 Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the towns of [Radkivka](/w/index.php?title=Radkivka&action=edit&redlink=1 "Radkivka (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A0%D0%B0%D0%B4%D1%8C%D0%BA%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%9A%D1%83%D0%BF%27%D1%8F%D0%BD%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Радьківка (Куп'янський район)")\
\], north of [Kupiansk](/wiki/Kupiansk "Kupiansk")
 and [Dachne](/wiki/Dachne,_Novopavlivka_hromada "Dachne, Novopavlivka hromada")
, south of [Novopavlivka](/wiki/Novopavlivka,_Synelnykove_Raion,_Dnipropetrovsk_Oblast "Novopavlivka, Synelnykove Raion, Dnipropetrovsk Oblast")
.[\[277\]](#cite_note-russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-july-24-2025-277)

A Hungarian citizen who joined the Ukrainian Army in 2024 was charged in absentia "illegally joining an armed group involved in an armed conflict outside the territory of allied forces" by the Hungarian prosecutor's office in [Csongrád-Csanád County](/wiki/Csongr%C3%A1d-Csan%C3%A1d_County "Csongrád-Csanád County")
.[\[278\]](#cite_note-278)

The US Department of Defense approved a military aid package valued at $322 million, including HAWK missiles, maintenance equipment and Bradley Vehicles.[\[279\]](#cite_note-279)

Ukrainian drones struck several parts of Rostov Oblast, injuring three people, setting fire to the [Novocherkassk](/wiki/Novocherkassk "Novocherkassk")
 power plant, and disrupting rail, [Rostelecom](/wiki/Rostelecom "Rostelecom")
 and electricity services.[\[280\]](#cite_note-280)

### 24 July

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/NASA_FIRMS_2025-07-23_Sochi.png/250px-NASA_FIRMS_2025-07-23_Sochi.png)](/wiki/File:NASA_FIRMS_2025-07-23_Sochi.png)

[NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")
's [FIRMS](/wiki/Fire_Information_for_Resource_Management_System "Fire Information for Resource Management System")
 detected a fire on 23 July 2025 22:03:00 ([UTC](/wiki/UTC "UTC")
) at the Sochi Lukoil fuel depot

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-07-24_%2805%29.jpg/250px-Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-07-24_%2805%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Destructions_in_Odesa_after_Russian_attack,_2025-07-24_(05).jpg)

Apartment building in Odesa after the attack

Two people were killed in a Russian attack in Donetsk Oblast.[\[274\]](#cite_note-khd-274)

Multiple buildings in Odesa, including the [Pryvoz Market](/wiki/Pryvoz_Market "Pryvoz Market")
 and historic buildings on [Prymorskyi Boulevard](/wiki/Prymorskyi_Boulevard "Prymorskyi Boulevard")
, were damaged in a Russian airstrike.[\[281\]](#cite_note-281)
[\[282\]](#cite_note-282)

Ukrainian drones attacked [Sochi](/wiki/Sochi "Sochi")
 and caused a fire in the Lukoil fuel depot with locals reporting at least seven explosions in the sky.[\[283\]](#cite_note-283)
 Russian air defence, ranging from small arms to S-300/400 missiles, engaged the drones "flying directly over residential buildings."[\[284\]](#cite_note-284)
 Two people were killed.[\[285\]](#cite_note-285)

An Israeli [Red Color](/wiki/Red_Color "Red Color")
 radar designed to plot impact zones for rockets and drones and allowing for more timely warnings for civilians became active in Kyiv.[\[286\]](#cite_note-286)

Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces took the village of [Yablunivka](/w/index.php?title=Yablunivka,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Yablunivka, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
, northwest of Toretsk and the Russian defense ministry claimed that Russian forces took the rural settlement of [Novoekonomichne](/wiki/Novoekonomichne "Novoekonomichne")
, northeast of Pokrovsk and the village of [Zvirove](/w/index.php?title=Zvirove&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zvirove (page does not exist)")
, southwest of Pokrovsk.[\[277\]](#cite_note-russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-july-24-2025-277)

The European Union announced that it was suspending all financial assistance to Ukraine until the "independent powers of its anti- corruption institutions are restored."[\[287\]](#cite_note-287)

### 25 July

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Kharkiv_Regional_Tuberculosis_Hospital_No._3_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-07-25_%2810%29.jpg/250px-Kharkiv_Regional_Tuberculosis_Hospital_No._3_after_Russian_attack%2C_2025-07-25_%2810%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kharkiv_Regional_Tuberculosis_Hospital_No._3_after_Russian_attack,_2025-07-25_(10).jpg)

Kharkiv Regional Tuberculosis Hospital No. Geolocated footage showed that Russian forces advanced to the center of [Katerynivka](/w/index.php?title=Katerynivka,_Illinivka_rural_hromada&action=edit&redlink=1 "Katerynivka, Illinivka rural hromada (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%86%D0%BB%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0) "uk:Катеринівка (Іллінівська сільська громада)")\
\], northwest of Toretsk and central [Shcherbynivka](/wiki/Shcherbynivka "Shcherbynivka")
, indicating that Russian forces likely recently completed the [seizure of Toretsk](/wiki/Battle_of_Toretsk "Battle of Toretsk")
.[\[374\]](#cite_note-374)

The HUR claimed to have carried out a series of attacks in Crimea that destroyed or damaged three Russian radar stations and a [Project 02510 BK-16](/wiki/Raptor-class_patrol_boat "Raptor-class patrol boat")
 landing craft.[\[375\]](#cite_note-375)

### 8 August

Geolocated footage showed that Ukrainian forces retained positions in [Katerynivka](/w/index.php?title=Katerynivka,_Illinivka_rural_hromada&action=edit&redlink=1 "Katerynivka, Illinivka rural hromada (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%86%D0%BB%D0%BB%D1%96%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0) "uk:Катеринівка (Іллінівська сільська громада)")\
\] and parts of Shcherbynivka, both near Toretsk, while Russian forces advanced into central [Rusyn Yar](/w/index.php?title=Rusyn_Yar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Rusyn Yar (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A0%D1%83%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%BD_%D0%AF%D1%80 "uk:Русин Яр")\
\] and seized [Poltavka](/w/index.php?title=Poltavka,_Kostiantynivka_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Poltavka, Kostiantynivka Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0_(%D0%9A%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8F%D0%BD%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Полтавська сільська рада (Костянтинівський район)")\
\].[\[376\]](#cite_note-376)

Ukraine imposed sanctions on [Rosatom](/wiki/Rosatom "Rosatom")
 and 34 other individuals and entities involved in bypassing energy-related sanctions against Russia and in the occupation of the [Zaporizhzhia](/wiki/Zaporizhzhia_Nuclear_Power_Plant "Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant")
 and [Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plants](/wiki/Chernobyl_Nuclear_Power_Plant "Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant")
.[\[377\]](#cite_note-377)

The HUR claimed to have carried out an attack on Russia's [90th Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade](/w/index.php?title=90th_Anti-Aircraft_Missile_Brigade&action=edit&redlink=1 "90th Anti-Aircraft Missile Brigade (page does not exist)")
 in Krasnodar Krai, killing 12 and injuring dozens more, as well as destroying military equipment.[\[378\]](#cite_note-378)

A Ukrainian drone targeted the "[Voronezh-M](/wiki/Voronezh_radar "Voronezh radar")
" radar station near [Orsk](/wiki/Orsk "Orsk")
 in [Orenburg Oblast](/wiki/Orenburg_Oblast "Orenburg Oblast")
, making it the longest one-way drone attack ever with the distance of over 1,800 kilometers.[\[379\]](#cite_note-379)

### 9 August

Two people were killed in a Russian drone strike on a bus in Kherson.[\[380\]](#cite_note-380)
 During the rescue operation, Russian forces launched another attack, injuring three police officers.[\[381\]](#cite_note-381)

### 10 August

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-10_Saratov.png/250px-NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-10_Saratov.png)](/wiki/File:NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-10_Saratov.png)

[NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA")
's [FIRMS](/wiki/Fire_Information_for_Resource_Management_System "Fire Information for Resource Management System")
 detected extensive fire on August 10 00:39:00 ([UTC](/wiki/UTC "UTC")
) at the [Saratov](/wiki/Saratov "Saratov")
 oil refinery

Three swimmers were killed by sea mines in the Black Sea off the coast of [Odesa Oblast](/wiki/Odesa_Oblast "Odesa Oblast")
.[\[382\]](#cite_note-382)

The Ukrainian military claimed to have retaken the village of [Bezsalivka](/wiki/Bezsalivka "Bezsalivka")
 in Sumy Oblast following an operation that killed 18 Russian soldiers,[\[383\]](#cite_note-383)
 but a Russian milblogger reportedly affiliated with the Russian [Northern Group of Forces](/wiki/Northern_Group_of_Forces_(Russia) "Northern Group of Forces (Russia)")
 refuted the claim.[\[384\]](#cite_note-384)

Ukrainian drones attacked the [Saratov](/wiki/Saratov "Saratov")
 oil refinery with reports of numerous explosions in the early morning and [social media](/wiki/Social_media "Social media")
 videos showing massive fires and black smoke associated with burning oil products.[\[385\]](#cite_note-385)
 [Collateral damage](/wiki/Collateral_damage "Collateral damage")
 from falling drone debris included one fatality.[\[386\]](#cite_note-386)

The [Ukrainian Air Force](/wiki/Ukrainian_Air_Force "Ukrainian Air Force")
 conducted a "high-precision bomb strike" against a Russian battalion headquarters in [Oleshky](/wiki/Oleshky "Oleshky")
, Kherson Oblast, claiming to have killed 25 soldiers, including the battalion commander, and injured 11.[\[387\]](#cite_note-387)

### 11 August

Main article: [Dobropillia offensive](/wiki/Dobropillia_offensive "Dobropillia offensive")

DeepStateMap reported that Russian forces had reached the [Dobropillia](/wiki/Dobropillia "Dobropillia")
–[Kramatorsk](/wiki/Kramatorsk "Kramatorsk")
 highway, advanced near the town of [Vesele](/w/index.php?title=Vesele,_Shakhove_rural_hromada,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vesele, Shakhove rural hromada, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%92%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5_(%D0%A8%D0%B0%D1%85%D1%96%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0) "uk:Веселе (Шахівська сільська громада)")\
\] in Donetsk Oblast[\[388\]](#cite_note-388)
 and entered the settlements of [Kucheriv Yar](/w/index.php?title=Kucheriv_Yar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kucheriv Yar (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9A%D1%83%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%96%D0%B2_%D0%AF%D1%80 "uk:Кучерів Яр")\
\] and [Zoloty Kolodiaz](/w/index.php?title=Zoloty_Kolodiaz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zoloty Kolodiaz (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B4%D1%8F%D0%B7%D1%8C "uk:Золотий Колодязь")\
\].[\[389\]](#cite_note-389)
 NASA's [Fire Information for Resource Management System](/wiki/Fire_Information_for_Resource_Management_System "Fire Information for Resource Management System")
 reported heat anomalies west of [Nove Shakhove](/w/index.php?title=Nove_Shakhove&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nove Shakhove (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5_%D0%A8%D0%B0%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B5 "uk:Нове Шахове")\
\] and in [Novyi Donbas](/w/index.php?title=Novyi_Donbas&action=edit&redlink=1 "Novyi Donbas (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%81 "uk:Новий Донбас")\
\], east of Dobropillia, [Bilytske](/wiki/Bilytske "Bilytske")
, southeast of Dobropillia, and [Rodynske](/wiki/Rodynske "Rodynske")
, leading the ISW to assess that Russian forces likely recently seized [Razine](/w/index.php?title=Razine,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Razine, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A0%D0%B0%D0%B7%D1%96%D0%BD%D0%B5_(%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Разіне (Покровський район)")\
\], [Sukhetske](/w/index.php?title=Sukhetske&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sukhetske (page does not exist)")
, [Fedorivka](/w/index.php?title=Fedorivka,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Fedorivka, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%A4%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0_(%D0%9F%D0%BE%D0%BA%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B9%D0%BE%D0%BD) "uk:Федорівка (Покровський район)")\
\], [Zatyshok](/wiki/Zatyshok,_Donetsk_Oblast "Zatyshok, Donetsk Oblast")
, [Boikivka](/w/index.php?title=Boikivka&action=edit&redlink=1 "Boikivka (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%91%D0%BE%D0%B9%D0%BA%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0 "uk:Бойківка")\
\], [Novotoretske](/w/index.php?title=Novotoretske,_Shakhove_rural_hromada,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Novotoretske, Shakhove rural hromada, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9D%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%86%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B5_(%D0%A8%D0%B0%D1%85%D1%96%D0%B2%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D1%81%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%81%D1%8C%D0%BA%D0%B0_%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B0%D0%B4%D0%B0) "uk:Новоторецьке (Шахівська сільська громада)")\
\], [Zapovidne](/w/index.php?title=Zapovidne&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zapovidne (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%97%D0%B0%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%96%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_(%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%BE) "uk:Заповідне (село)")\
\], [Nykanorivka](/w/index.php?title=Nykanorivka&action=edit&redlink=1 "Nykanorivka (page does not exist)")
,[\[390\]](#cite_note-russian-offensive-campaign-assessment-august-13-2025-390)
 southeast of Dobropillia, and the towns of [Maiak](/wiki/Maiak,_Pokrovsk_Raion,_Donetsk_Oblast "Maiak, Pokrovsk Raion, Donetsk Oblast")
, and [Pankivka](/w/index.php?title=Pankivka,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pankivka, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
 \[[uk](https://uk.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%9F%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%96%D0%B2%D0%BA%D0%B0 "uk:Панківка")\
\], east of Dobropillia.[\[391\]](#cite_note-391)
 A day later, spokesperson for the [Dnipro operational-strategic group](/wiki/Dnipro_operational-strategic_group "Dnipro operational-strategic group")
, Colonel [Viktor Trehubov](/w/index.php?title=Viktor_Trehubov&action=edit&redlink=1 "Viktor Trehubov (page does not exist)")
, denied any breakthroughs in the area.[\[392\]](#cite_note-392)

Geolocated footage indicated that Russian forces captured the town of Zelenyi Hai.[\[393\]](#cite_note-393)

The Ukrainian military claimed to have killed the commander of the Russian [85th Motorized Rifle Brigade](/w/index.php?title=85th_Motorized_Rifle_Brigade&action=edit&redlink=1 "85th Motorized Rifle Brigade (page does not exist)")
 who goes by the callsign "Dniepr" and five other soldiers in an attack on a command post in Donetsk Oblast.[\[394\]](#cite_note-394)

The Orenburg Helium Plant and the Monocrystal JSC plant in [Stavropol](/wiki/Stavropol "Stavropol")
 were attacked by Ukrainian drones.[\[395\]](#cite_note-395)

### 12 August

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-12_Unecha.png/250px-NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-12_Unecha.png)](/wiki/File:NASA_FIRMS_2025-08-12_Unecha.png)

) at the [Unecha](/wiki/Unecha "Unecha")
 junction of the [Druzhba pipeline](/wiki/Druzhba_pipeline "Druzhba pipeline")

A Ukrainian soldier was killed in a Russian cluster munitions attack on an undisclosed training facility.[\[396\]](#cite_note-396)

Ukrainian drones caused a fire at the [Unecha](/wiki/Unecha "Unecha")
 junction of the [Druzhba pipeline](/wiki/Druzhba_pipeline "Druzhba pipeline")
 in [Bryansk Oblast](/wiki/Bryansk_Oblast "Bryansk Oblast")
.[\[397\]](#cite_note-397)

, in a podcast interview with [Sid Rosenberg](/wiki/Sid_Rosenberg "Sid Rosenberg")
, claimed that the Russians had lost 60,000 dead in July alone, which he said indicated Russia's commitment to the war.[\[399\]](#cite_note-n644-399)

### 13 August

 and [Zapovidne](/w/index.php?title=Zapovidne,_Donetsk_Oblast&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zapovidne, Donetsk Oblast (page does not exist)")
, near Dobropillia.[\[401\]](#cite_note-401)

 in an undisclosed location.[\[402\]](#cite_note-402)

    ."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Wikipedia provides a timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, including events from June 1, 2025, to the present. It mentions several events in June, July, and August 2025, including:

*   June 1: A Russian missile strike on a training ground near Dnipro, killing twelve Ukrainian soldiers.
*   June 2: Russia and Ukraine held peace negotiations in Istanbul, Turkey.
*   June 3: A Russian airstrike on Sumy killed six people.
*   June 11: A Russian drone attack on Kharkiv killed three people.
*   June 17: A Russian air attack on Kyiv killed at least 30 people and injured 172.
*   June 18: Russia and Ukraine conducted a fifth prisoner exchange.
*   June 20: A Russian drone attack on Odesa killed one person.
*   July 22: A Russian airstrike in Kramatorsk killed one person.
*   July 23: Russia said that it agreed to exchange more POWs at peace negotiations with Ukraine held in Istanbul.
*   July 24: A Russian airstrike in Odesa damaged multiple buildings.
*   August 8: Ukraine imposed sanctions on Rosatom.
*   August 9: A Russian drone strike on a bus in Kherson killed two people.
*   August 10: Ukrainian drones attacked the Saratov oil refinery.
*   August 11: Russian forces entered the settlements of Kucheriv Yar and Zoloty Kolodiaz.
*   August 12: Ukrainian drones caused a fire at the Unecha junction of the Druzhba pipeline.
*   August 14: Ukrainian drones set fire to an oil refinery in Novoshakhtinsk.
*   August 21: A Ukrainian national was arrested in Italy on suspicion of co-masterminding the Nord Stream pipelines sabotage.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In early 2025, Ukraine and Russia had reached a peace deal in their years-long war."

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine Russia peace deal 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Guardian published an article on August 21, 2025, stating that Donald Trump is taking a step back from negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, mentioning a meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy on August 18, 2025, at the White House (<image:4898>) ([https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks)). Wikipedia discusses peace negotiations in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mentioning a timeline of the war, including events up to December 2024 and a timeline for 2025, and a meeting between Trump, Macron, and Zelenskyy in December 2024 ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine)).

CNN published an article on August 19, 2025, discussing the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal in the context of the war between Ukraine and Russia (<image:0>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>, <image:4>) ([https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl)). The article mentions that Donald Trump is pushing for a peace deal, while Ukraine wants a ceasefire.


## Elaboration
The evidence suggests that peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia were ongoing in 2025. The Guardian reported on August 21, 2025, that Trump was stepping back from negotiations, and CNN discussed the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal on August 19, 2025.

However, the evidence does not explicitly state that a peace deal was reached in early 2025. While there were discussions and negotiations, the articles suggest that a deal was not yet finalized, as Trump was involved in negotiations in August 2025.

Therefore, the claim cannot be verified based on the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm whether a peace deal was reached in early 2025.


## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine Russia peace deal early 2025 timeline")
```

From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/30/russia-ukraine-war-list-of-key-events-day-1283): 
Content: "He also claimed that 62 percent of key enterprises in “Ukraine’s military-industrial complex” suffered damage.
    
*   Emergency crews have completed rescue operations in the aftermath of a huge Russian drone and missile attack on the Ukrainian capital Kyiv in the early hours of Thursday, as authorities revised the death toll from the attack upward to 25.

Weapons
-------

*   The United States Department of State has approved the potential sale of Patriot air defence system sustainment and related equipment to Ukraine for an estimated cost of $179.1m, the Pentagon said.

Peace talks
-----------

*   Deadly missile and drone [strikes on Ukraine](/news/2025/8/28/massive-russian-attack-on-ukraines-kyiv-kills-at-least-4-dozens-hurt)
     “cast doubt on the seriousness of Russia’s desire for peace”, the US told the United Nations Security Council, warning that Washington could punish Moscow with economic measures if it continues the war.
*   Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko told the UNSC that “Russia continues to choose killing over ending the war” with its continued attacks.
*   Russia’s deputy UN ambassador, Dmitry Polyanskiy, said Moscow was prepared to consider a summit with Ukraine “provided that there is thorough prior preparation for such a meeting and the substantive content of it; otherwise, it would simply not have any meaning”.
*   Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has urged allies to swiftly elevate talks on security guarantees for Ukraine to the level of leaders, as European Union defence ministers pledged to train Kyiv’s troops on Ukrainian soil in the event of a truce with Russia.
*   European defence ministers meeting in Copenhagen expressed “broad support” for expanding the bloc’s military training mission to operate inside Ukraine, the EU’s top diplomat, Kaja Kallas, said.
*   President Zelenskyy said he expected to continue talks with European leaders next week on “NATO-like” commitments to protect Ukraine, adding that US President Donald Trump should also be involved in the discussions.
*   The Ukrainian leader also said he wanted Ukraine’s allies to ratify any security guarantees through their parliaments, invoking a 1994 deal in which Kyiv agreed to give up its nuclear arsenal in exchange for security assurances that proved insufficient to deter Russia’s invasion.
*   Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said proposals on security guarantees for Ukraine would increase the risk of conflict between Moscow and the West by turning Kyiv into a “strategic provocateur” on Russia’s borders.
*   Estonia’s Defence Minister Hanno Pevkur said the best security guarantee for Ukraine would be membership in NATO.

Fighting
--------

*   The Ukrainian military said it had carried out an overnight strike on a facility in Russia’s Bryansk region that was responsible for the flow of diesel fuelling Moscow’s war effort in Ukraine.
    
*   Kyiv’s General Staff said the fuel pumping station in the village of Naitopovichi had a capacity of approximately 10.5 million tonnes per year, and that the strike had caused a fire.
    
*   Russian Defence Minister Andrei Belousov said the Russian army had sped up its rate of advance in Ukraine and was taking control of some 600 to 700 square kilometres (231- 270sq miles) each month compared to 300-400 square kilometres (115-154sq miles) at the start of this year.
    
*   Belousov also said that Russia had inflicted significant damage on Ukraine’s military and industrial infrastructure, carrying out 35 strikes this year on what he called 146 critically important targets. The article discusses recent attacks, including a Russian strike on Kyiv that killed 25 people, and mentions that peace talks are ongoing. It also mentions that the US told the United Nations Security Council that deadly strikes "cast doubt on the seriousness of Russia’s desire for peace." <image:0>.

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/turkey-peace-talks-russia-ukraine-invasion-timeline-b2750560.html): 
Content: "Ukrainian officials are not invited.

**February 28, 2025:** Zelenskyy meets with Trump, Rubio and Vice President JD Vance in the White House but tensions break out in the Oval Office and a proposed minerals deal between the countries is left unsigned.

!Russia Ukraine Diplomacy Timeline <image:8199>

open image in gallery

Russia Ukraine Diplomacy Timeline (Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. Talks continue over the next two weeks, but no apparent agreements emerge other than a decision to set up humanitarian corridors for civilians.

!Russia Ukraine Diplomacy Timeline <image:8196>

open image in gallery

Russia Ukraine Diplomacy Timeline (Sputnik)

**March 21, 2022:** Zelenskyy calls for direct talks with Putin but is rebuffed by Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov. A day later, Zelenskyy says he is prepared to discuss a commitment for Ukraine to not to seek NATO membership in exchange for a ceasefire, the withdrawal of Russian troops and a guarantee of Ukraine’s security.

**March 29, 2022:** Talks begin in Istanbul, Turkey, with Moscow saying it's willing to “fundamentally cut back” military activity near Kyiv and the northern city of Chernihiv, while Ukraine said it was open to discussing neutral status for Ukraine if its security is backed by other nations.

**April 7, 2022:** Lavrov rejects a Ukrainian peace proposal as “unacceptable. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin calls his Russian counterpart, Sergei Shoigu, in their first contact since before the start of the war.

**July 22, 2022:** Russia and Ukraine, with mediation by Turkey and the U.N., agree on a deal to unblock supplies of grain stuck in Ukraine’s Black Sea ports, ending a standoff that threatened global food security. Ukraine responds by applying to join NATO and by enacting a decree that declares negotiations with Putin “impossible”.

**November 15, 2022:** Zelenskyy unveils a 10-point peace plan at the G20 summit in Bali.

**June 25, 2023:** Officials from 15 countries, including the U.S., the European Union, India, Brazil, South Africa, Saudi Arabia, and Turkey meet in Copenhagen, Denmark, to discuss Zelenskyy’s peace plan.

**August 5, 2023:** Two days of discussions on the war begin in Saudi Arabia with delegates from 40 countries, but not Russia. Russia, which has dismissed the talks, was not invited.

**June 15, 2024:** Representatives of 92 nations meet in Nidwalden, Switzerland, to discuss Ukraine’s peace plan. President-elect [Donald Trump](/topic/donald-trump)
 travels to Paris and meets Zelenskyy and other European leaders.

!Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin hold a bilateral meeting at the G20 leaders summit in Osaka, Japan, 28 June 2019 <image:8198>

open image in gallery

Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin hold a bilateral meeting at the G20 leaders summit in Osaka, Japan, 28 June 2019 (Reuters)

**February 12, 2025:** Trump and Putin speak directly via telephone and agree to begin negotiations on ending Ukraine war in a phone call that abruptly ended a three-year U.S.-led effort to isolate Putin over Ukraine.

**February 18, 2025:** Russian and U.S. Both sides agree to the plan, but soon accuse each other of violations, and the measure later expires.

**April 19, 2025:** Putin announces a 30-hour ceasefire to mark the Easter holiday, although attacks continue across Ukraine.

**April 28, 2025:** The Kremlin declares a unilateral 72-hour ceasefire starting May 8 to mark Russia's Victory Day celebrating the defeat of Nazi Germany in World War II. <image:8200>

open image in gallery

(POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

**May 10, 2025:** French President Emmanuel Macron, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk meet with Zelenskyy in Kyiv and urge Russia to enact a 30-day truce starting May 12.

**May 11, 2025:** Putin proposes restarting direct talks with Ukraine in Istanbul on May 15, “without preconditions,” but does not agree to the 30-day ceasefire Zelenskyy challenges Putin to meet personally in Turkey.

! Stay up to date with notifications from The Independent
-------------------------------------------------------

Notifications can be managed in browser preferences.

Not nowYes please

Next article

It was a weekend of diplomatic announcements on the war in [Ukraine](/topic/ukraine)
.

First, European leaders assembled in [Kyiv](/topic/kyiv)
 on Saturday with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to put pressure on Russian President [Vladimir Putin](/topic/vladimir-putin)
 for a ceasefire."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Independent published a timeline of the Russia-Ukraine war. On February 28, 2025, Zelenskyy met with Trump in the White House, but tensions arose, and a proposed minerals deal was left unsigned (<image:8199>). On February 12, 2025, Trump and Putin spoke directly and agreed to begin negotiations. On February 18, 2025, both sides agreed to a plan, but soon accused each other of violations. On April 19, 2025, Putin announced a 30-hour ceasefire. On May 10, 2025, European leaders met with Zelenskyy in Kyiv and urged Russia to enact a 30-day truce. On May 11, 2025, Putin proposed restarting direct talks with Ukraine in Istanbul on May 15.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In early 2025, Ukraine and Russia had reached a peace deal in their years-long war."

## Actions
```
web_search("Ukraine Russia peace deal 2025")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `web_search`
The Guardian published an article on August 21, 2025, stating that Donald Trump is taking a step back from negotiations to end the war in Ukraine, mentioning a meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy on August 18, 2025, at the White House (<image:4898>) ([https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/aug/21/trump-ukraine-russia-peace-talks)). Wikipedia discusses peace negotiations in the Russian invasion of Ukraine, mentioning a timeline of the war, including events up to December 2024 and a timeline for 2025, and a meeting between Trump, Macron, and Zelenskyy in December 2024 ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peace_negotiations_in_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine)).

CNN published an article on August 19, 2025, discussing the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal in the context of the war between Ukraine and Russia (<image:0>, <image:1>, <image:2>, <image:3>, <image:4>) ([https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl](https://www.cnn.com/2025/08/19/europe/ukraine-ceasefire-peace-deal-difference-analysis-latam-intl)). The article mentions that Donald Trump is pushing for a peace deal, while Ukraine wants a ceasefire.


## Elaboration
The evidence suggests that peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia were ongoing in 2025. The Guardian reported on August 21, 2025, that Trump was stepping back from negotiations, and CNN discussed the difference between a ceasefire and a peace deal on August 19, 2025.

However, the evidence does not explicitly state that a peace deal was reached in early 2025. While there were discussions and negotiations, the articles suggest that a deal was not yet finalized, as Trump was involved in negotiations in August 2025.

Therefore, the claim cannot be verified based on the provided evidence. More information is needed to confirm whether a peace deal was reached in early 2025.

```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_present)): 
Content: The search result from Wikipedia provides a timeline of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, including events from June 1, 2025, to the present. It mentions several events in June, July, and August 2025, including:

*   June 1: A Russian missile strike on a training ground near Dnipro, killing twelve Ukrainian soldiers.
*   June 2: Russia and Ukraine held peace negotiations in Istanbul, Turkey.
*   June 3: A Russian airstrike on Sumy killed six people.
*   June 11: A Russian drone attack on Kharkiv killed three people.
*   June 17: A Russian air attack on Kyiv killed at least 30 people and injured 172.
*   June 18: Russia and Ukraine conducted a fifth prisoner exchange.
*   June 20: A Russian drone attack on Odesa killed one person.
*   July 22: A Russian airstrike in Kramatorsk killed one person.
*   July 23: Russia said that it agreed to exchange more POWs at peace negotiations with Ukraine held in Istanbul.
*   July 24: A Russian airstrike in Odesa damaged multiple buildings.
*   August 8: Ukraine imposed sanctions on Rosatom.
*   August 9: A Russian drone strike on a bus in Kherson killed two people.
*   August 10: Ukrainian drones attacked the Saratov oil refinery.
*   August 11: Russian forces entered the settlements of Kucheriv Yar and Zoloty Kolodiaz.
*   August 12: Ukrainian drones caused a fire at the Unecha junction of the Druzhba pipeline.
*   August 14: Ukrainian drones set fire to an oil refinery in Novoshakhtinsk.
*   August 21: A Ukrainian national was arrested in Italy on suspicion of co-masterminding the Nord Stream pipelines sabotage.


From [Source](https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2025/8/30/russia-ukraine-war-list-of-key-events-day-1283): 
Content: Al Jazeera published an article on August 30, 2025, detailing the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine. The article discusses recent attacks, including a Russian strike on Kyiv that killed 25 people, and mentions that peace talks are ongoing. It also mentions that the US told the United Nations Security Council that deadly strikes "cast doubt on the seriousness of Russia’s desire for peace." <image:0>.


From [Source](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/turkey-peace-talks-russia-ukraine-invasion-timeline-b2750560.html): 
Content: The Independent published a timeline of the Russia-Ukraine war. On February 28, 2025, Zelenskyy met with Trump in the White House, but tensions arose, and a proposed minerals deal was left unsigned (<image:8199>). On February 12, 2025, Trump and Putin spoke directly and agreed to begin negotiations. On February 18, 2025, both sides agreed to a plan, but soon accused each other of violations. On April 19, 2025, Putin announced a 30-hour ceasefire. On May 10, 2025, European leaders met with Zelenskyy in Kyiv and urged Russia to enact a 30-day truce. On May 11, 2025, Putin proposed restarting direct talks with Ukraine in Istanbul on May 15.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search results provide a timeline of events related to the Russia-Ukraine war in 2025. Wikipedia's timeline ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_present](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_present)) ) details events from June 1, 2025, to August 2025, including peace negotiations in Istanbul in June and July. JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "In early 2025, Ukraine and Russia had reached a peace deal in their years-long war."

```

### Evidence from `web_search`
The search results provide a timeline of events related to the Russia-Ukraine war in 2025. Wikipedia's timeline ([https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_present](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_Russian_invasion_of_Ukraine_(1_June_2025_%E2%80%93_present)) ) details events from June 1, 2025, to August 2025, including peace negotiations in Istanbul in June and July. Furthermore, the timeline includes a 30-hour ceasefire in April and proposals for further talks in May and June, suggesting that a final deal was not yet in place.

Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence.

The Independent mentions a meeting between Zelenskyy and Trump on February 28, 2025, and an agreement on February 18, 2025, but also reports violations. Furthermore, the timeline includes a 30-hour ceasefire in April and proposals for further talks in May and June, suggesting that a final deal was not yet in place. Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence. `false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence, including reports from The Guardian, CNN, and The Independent, indicates that peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia were ongoing in early 2025, with meetings and discussions taking place. However, the provided sources do not confirm that a peace deal was reached during that period. The Independent mentions an agreement in February 2025, but also reports violations, and the timeline includes ceasefires and proposals for further talks, suggesting that a final deal was not yet finalized. Therefore, the claim is not supported by the evidence.

PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `image_search`
   * Description: Run an image search on Google to retrieve related images for a given query.
   * How to use: This is a helpful tool for fact-checking images. Use this to retrieve images associated with a specific keyword or phrase. Ensure that the query is clear and specific to improve search accuracy. If no relevant images are found, refine the query or use more descriptive terms.
   * Format: image_search("your image search query goes here")

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: image_search()

## Claim
Text: "Chinese officials in white protective hazmat suits carried people down a hallway to be quarantined for having COVID-19 in November 2022."

...

ACTIONS:
```
image_search("China officials white suits carry people")
image_search("China officials carry people COVID quarantine 2022")
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "Half of all US aid to Ukraine was laundered and sent back to Democrat candidates for re-election."

## Actions
```
web_search("US aid to Ukraine laundered Democrat candidates")
```
